docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''What Ails Florida?,'' by Bob Herbert (column, Jan. 12): Our record clearly demonstrates that ensuring that children have access to affordable health care is a top priority in Florida. That's why we have expanded coverage for child health insurance dramatically.
docs.abstract: Letter from Fla Gov Jeb Bush defends his record on affordable health are for state's children

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiations between the union for workers at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Westchester County and its owners broke down last night, increasing the likelihood of a strike tonight, the union's president said. Manny Hellen, the president of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America, said a federal mediator had been called in to bring both sides back to the negotiating table.

headline.main: Indian Pt. Talks Falter on Eve of Strike Deadline

docs.abstract: Utility Workers Union of America will bring in mediator after talks with Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant owners break down; workers are negotiating with Entergy Corp for better health benefits and have threatened to strike if agreement is not reached by contract expiration (M)
docs.snippet: Negotiations between the union for workers at the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Westchester County and its owners broke down last night, increasing the likelihood of a strike tonight, the union's president said.       Manny Hellen, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Unless you're going to spontaneously combust like Krook in Dickens's ''Bleak House,'' something must be done with you when you die in New York, and that something requires a document. At some point, your name and Social Security number must cross a Health Department desk. Without a certified death certificate, survivors cannot begin probate on a will, make claims on life insurance policies, apply for Social Security benefits, or perform a host of other tasks involving the business of life.
docs.abstract: Metropolitan Funeral Directors Association exec dir Wilson H Beebe Jr Op-Ed article maintains that it can take funeral director two to six months to get death certificate because of New York City's antiquated death registration system; contends that families suffer financially since they cannot get survivors' benefits and insurance payments; holds that city is doing little to make things easier; notes that Mayor Michael R Bloomberg recently vetoed City Council measure that would have required New York to adopt electronic death registration system by Oct 2006; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Unless you're going to spontaneously combust like Krook in Dickens's ''Bleak House,'' something must be done with you when you die in New York, and that something requires a document. At some point, your name and Social Security number must cross a...

docs.lead_paragraph: The crowd was cheering and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri was working the microphone with his finger jabbing and his fist pounding. For months now, he has crisscrossed this state, promoting his experience as a leader in Congress, his promise to provide universal health insurance and his long commitment to fair trade and working families. But as the Iowa caucuses near, Mr. Gephardt has turned up the fire on a stump speech that once conveyed more plain-spoken sincerity than flash or flair. Locked in a four-way battle for Iowa caucus voters, Mr. Gephardt is working hard to engage his audience.

headline.main: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE STUMP SPEECH/Representative Richard A. Gephardt; A Washington Résumé, With a Heartland Call to Arms

docs.abstract: Third article in series looking at basic campaign speeches of Democratic presidential candidates notes that Rep Richard A Gephardt, in his stump speech, emphasizes his experience as leader in Congress and his plan for universal health care; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The crowd was cheering and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri was working the microphone with his finger jabbing and his fist pounding. For months now, he has crisscrossed this state, promoting his experience as a leader in Congress, his...

docs.lead_paragraph: In his stump speech, Representative Richard. A. Gephardt of Missouri emphasizes his experience and his plan for universal health care. Here is an excerpt from a speech on Jan. 9 in Williamsburg, Iowa, as recorded by The New York Times: In my first week as president, I will ask the Congress to lay aside the Bush tax cuts. They have not worked, and I will use that money to see to it that every person in this country has good health insurance that can never be taken away from them.

headline.main: 'It's the Only Plan That's Truly Universal'

docs.abstract: Excerpt from Democratic presidential candidate Richard A Gephardt's Jan 9 speech in Williamsburg, Iowa, in which he discussed his plan for universal health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AARP, the influential lobby for older Americans, said Friday that it would seek changes in the new Medicare law to allow the government to negotiate lower drug prices for beneficiaries if private insurers are unable to win big discounts. ''We are beginning an all-out effort to lower the high cost of prescription drugs,'' said William D. Novelli, chief executive of AARP.

headline.main: AARP, Its Eye on Drug Prices, Urges Change in New Law

docs.abstract: AARP will seek changes in new Medicare law to allow government to negotiate lower drug prices for beneficiaries if private insurers are unable to win big discounts (M)
docs.snippet: AARP, the influential lobby for older Americans, said Friday that it would seek changes in the new Medicare law to allow the government to negotiate lower drug prices for beneficiaries if private insurers are unable to win big discounts.    ''We are...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush is expected to propose a health care initiative in his State of the Union address to help the uninsured and the underinsured, White House advisers said on Friday. It was unclear how much the initiative, to be announced in the address on Tuesday, would cost at a time when Mr. Bush is under pressure because of a growing budget deficit. But White House officials have made clear that they do not want to cede the politically potent issue of health care to the Democratic presidential candidates, all of whom have made health care a centerpiece of their campaigns.

headline.main: Bush Looking at a New Health Care Initiative, Advisers Say

docs.abstract: White House advisers say Pres Bush is expected to propose health care initiative in his State of Union address to help uninsured and underinsured; Senate minority leader Tom Daschle, in pre-emptive critique of Bush's speech, urges him to make health care more affordable and available to American families; photo (M)

byline.original: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 47 percent, helped by insurance income and increases in orders at industrial businesses like plastics and jet engines. Net income rose to $4.56 billion, or 45 cents a share, from $3.1 billion, or 31 cents, in the period a year earlier, which included 14 cents a share in reinsurance expenses.

headline.main: G.E. Earnings Up 47%, Aided by Insurance Unit and More Industrial Orders

docs.abstract: General Electric reports 47 percent increase in earnings for fourth quarter, compared with year-ago period; net income rose to $4.56 billion from $3.1 billion year earlier; sales rose about 4 percent, to $36.96 billion from $35.51 billion; chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's emotional appeal for free trade is an understandable response to the stench of a Cambodian garbage dump, where he visits ''scavengers like Nhep Chanda, who spends her days rooting through filth'' (''Calling All Democrats,'' column, Jan. 14).

headline.main: Does Trade Help Or Hurt Workers?

docs.abstract: David Berman letter responds to Nicholas D Kristof Jan 14 Op-Ed column; contends that his 'emotional appeal' for free trade is understandable response following his visit with Nhep Chanda, Cambodian scavenger who spends her days rooting through garbage dump; maintains that free trade rewards abusive labor practices and child exploitation while penalizing fair wages, health plans and unions

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration's idea of spending $1.5 billion promoting marriage is one of those rather expensive but basically symbolic gestures that presidents like to make in election years. Mr. Bush's advisers may also hope that it will divert social conservatives from pressing for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriages. But as meaningless sops to powerful voting blocs go, this one is particularly cruel. The whole idea of encouraging poor people to get married and stay married through classes and counseling sessions ignores the main reason that stable wedlock is rare in inner cities: the epidemics of joblessness and incarceration that have stripped those communities of what social scientists call ''marriageable'' men. Women in poor neighborhoods may find bitter amusement in the idea that they need the government's encouragement to search for a husband, or that conflict resolution courses are the way to shore up troubled unions between two poor people.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Bush administration's idea of spending $1.5 billion promoting marriage is one of those expensive but basically symbolic gestures that presidents like to make in election years; says Bush's advisers may also hope that it will divert social conservatives from pressing for constitutional amendment banning gay marriages
